intro: Draba parryoides, commonly known as Parry's whitlow grass, is a small flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes mustard and cress plants, and is characterized by its cruciform flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or alpine environments, preferring well-drained soils and full sun. It has basal leaves that are linear to lanceolate and produces small, yellowish-white flowers in early spring. Draba parryoides is often found in open habitats such as meadows and slopes, and it plays a role in stabilizing soil in arid regions.
